description: TO PASS THE BILL (1 STAT 73, APP. 9-24-1789), TO ESTABLISH THE JUDICIAL COURTS OF THE UNITED STATES.

TO AMEND THE ACT (1 STAT 28, APP. 7-27-1789), FOR ESTABLISH- ING AN EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT, TO BE DENOMINATED THE DEPART- MENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS; SO AS TO STRIKE THE WORDS "BY THE PRESIDENT", IN THE SECTION DEALING WITH THE APPOINTMENT OF A CHIEF CLERK.
TO CONCUR IN THE ACT (1 STAT 28, APP. 7-27-1789), TO ESTABLISH AN EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT TO BE KNOWN AS THE DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS.

TO AMEND THE ACT (1 STAT 49, APP. 8-7-1789), TO ESTABLISH AN EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT TO BE CALLED THE DEPARTMENT OF WAR; SO AS TO STRIKE "AND WHO, WHENEVER THE SAID PRINCIPAL OFFICER SHALL BE REMOVED FROM OFFICE BY THE PRESIDENT."
TO AMEND THE ACT (1 STAT 50, APP. 8-7-1789), TO PROVIDE FOR THE GOVERNMENT OF THE TERRITORY NORTHWEST OF THE OHIO RIVER; SO AS TO MAKE THE PRESIDENT'S ACTS UNDER THE BILL, SUBJECT TO SENATE APPROVAL.

TO AMEND THE ACT (1 STAT 54, APP. 8-20-1789), TO PROVIDE FOR THE EXPENSES OF NEGOTIATIONS OR TREATIES WITH THE INDIAN TRIBES, AND THE APPOINTMENT OF COMMISSIONERS; SO AS TO CHANGE THE LIMIT OF THE SUM TO BE EXPENDED IN NEGOTIATING A TREATY WITH THE INDIAS, FROM, $40,000 TO $20,000.

TO RECEDE FROM DISAGREEMENT TO A HOUSE AMENDMENT TO THE BILL (1 STAT 65, APP. 9-2-1789), TO ESTABLISH A TREASURY DEPT.; SAID AMENDMENT PROVIDES THAT IN THE ABSENCE OF A SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY, THE ASSISTANT SHALL HAVE CHARGE OF THE OFFICE.  (VICE PRESDENT VOTING IN THE AFFIRMATIVE)
TO PASS THE RESOLUTION THAT THERE OUGHT TO BE A DISCRIMINA- TION BETWEEN THE COMPENSATION ALLOWED TO SENATORS AND TO REPRESENTATIVES.

TO AMEND THE ACT (1 STAT 70, APP. 9-22-89), TO ALLOW COMPENSATION TO THE MEMBERS OF CONGRESS AND TO THE OFFICERS OF BOTH HOUSES, SO AS TO REDUCE THE COMPENSATION FOR REPRESENTATIVES FROM SIX TO FIVE DOLLARS.
TO AMEND THE COMPENSATION BILL TO REDUCE THE COMPENSATION TO THE SENATORS FROM SIX DOLLARS TO FIVE.

TO AMEND THE HOUSE RESOLUTION TO PROPOSE CERTAIN ARTICLES TO THE LEGISLATURES OF THE STATES AS AMENDMENTS TO THE CONSTITUTION; SO AS TO AMEND THE FIRST CLAUSE TO STATE "AFTER THE FIRST ENUMERATION REQUIRED BY THE FIRST ARTICLE OF THE CONSTITUTION, THERE HALL BE ONE REPRESENTATIVE FOR EVERY 30,000 UNTIL THE NUMBER SHALL AMOUNT TO TWO HUNDRED."
TO AMEND THE CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT RESOLUTION TO ADD TO THE FOURTH ARTICLE, AFTER THE WORDS "COMMON GOOD", THE WORDS "TO INSTRUCT THEIR REPRESENTATIVES."

TO AMEND THE CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT RESOLUTION TO ADD TO THE 5TH ARTICLE THE PROVISION THAT THE MILITARY SHOULD BE UNDER STRICT SUBORDINATION TO AND GOVERNED BY THE CIVIL POWER, ALSO THAT NO TROOPS SHALL BE RAISED DURING PEACE TIME WITHOUT CONSENT OF 23RDS OF THE MEMBERS OF CONGRESS, AND THAT NO SOLDIERS SHALL BE ENLISTED FOR LONGER THAN THE DURATION OF THE WAR.
TO INSIST ON THE SENATE AMENDMENT TO THE COMPENSATION BILL, THAT NO SENATOR SHALL RECEIVE MORE THAN $6.00 PER DAY FROM THE END OF ONE SESSION TO THE NEXT.
TO RECONSIDER AN AMENDMENT TO THE CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT RESOLUTION, TO RESTORE CERTAIN WORDS TO THE TENTH ARTICLE REGARDING TRIALS OF NAVAL CREWS.

TO AMEND THE ACT (1 STAT 101, APP. 3-1-90), TO ALLOW COMPEN- SATION TO THE JUDGES OF THE SUPREME COURT AND OTHER COURTS, AND TO THE ATTORNEY GENERAL; TO INCREASE THE SALARY OF THE CHIEF JUSTICE FROM $3500 TO $4000.  (VICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE AFFIRMATVE)
TO AMEND H.R. 25, (1 STAT 130, APP. 7-16-1790), TO ESTABLISH THE SEAT OF THE U.S. GOVERNMENT; SO AS TO ELIMINATE PA., AS A SITE FOR A PERMANENT SEAT OF GOVERNMENT.
TO AMEND H.R. 25, TO ELIMINATE THE "BANKS OF THE SUSQUEHANNA RIVER IN PENNSYLVANIA" AS A SITE FOR THE SEAT OF GOVERNMENT.
TO AMEND H.R. 25, TO INSERT, AS POSSIBLE SITES, CERTAIN COUNTIES IN THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA, INCLUDING GERMANTOWN AND PHILADELPHIA.  (VICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE AFFIRMATIVE)
TO AMEND H.R. 25, TO STRIKE "AND THAT UNTIL THE NECESSARY BUILDINGS SHALL BE ERECTED THEREIN, THE SEAT OF THE GOVERNMENT SHALL CONTINUE AT THE CITY OF NEW YORK."
TO PASS H.R. 25.
TO AGREE TO THE COMMITTEE REPORT THAT UNFINISHED BUSINESS BETWEEN THE TWO HOUSES AT THE LAST ADJOURNMENT, OUGHT TO BE REGARDED AS IF IT HAD NOT BEEN PASSED UPON BY EITHER HOUSE.

TO ORDER A THIRD READING FOR THE BILL TO PREVENT BRINGING GOODS, WARES AND MERCHANDISE FROM THE STATE OF RHODE ISLAND AND PROVIDENCE PLANTATIONS, INTO THE U.S., AND TO AUTHORIZE A DEMAND OF MONEY FROM THAT STATE.
TO PASS THE BILL TO PREVENT BRINGING GOODS, WARES, AND MERCHANDISE FROM RHODE ISLAND AND PROVIDENCE PLANTATIONS, INTO THE U.S., AND TO AUTHORIZE A DEMAND OF MONEY FROM THAT STATE.

TO ADOPT THE HOUSE RESOLUTION TO DIRECT THE SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY TO LIQUIDATE ARREARAGES OF PAY DUE CERTAIN NON-COMMISSIONED OFFICERS AND SOLDIERS; PAYMENT TO BE MADE WHEN CERTAIN CONDITIONS ARE MET.
TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT TO THE HOUSE RESOLUTION CONCERNING ARREARAGES OF PAY DUE CERTAIN NON-COMMISSIONED OFFICERS AND SOLDIERS; AMENDMENT CONCERNING POWERS OF ATTORNEY OBTAINED BY FORGERY OR FRAUD.
TO AGREE TO THE COMMITTEE REPORT WHICH RECOMMENDS GRANTING AN ANNUITY TO BARON DE STEUBEN.
TO DECIDE IF THE SUM OF TWO THOUSAND DOLLARS WILL REMAIN IN THE ACT (6 STAT 2, APP. 6-4-90), TO ADJUST THE CLAIM OF BARON DE STEUBEN.  (VICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE AFFIRMATIVE.)
TO AMEND THE STEUBEN BILL TO ELIMINATE THE PROVISION FOR A SUM OF $7000, IN ADDITION TO THE MONEY ALREADY RECEIVED BY HIM.  (VICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE NEGATIVE)
TO AMEND THE STEUBEN BILL TO CHANGE TO $2500, THE SUM TO BE PAID DE STEUBEN.  (VICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE AFFIRMATIVE)
TO CONCUR IN THE HOUSE RESOLUTION THAT CONGRESS SHALL MEET AND HOLD THEIR NEXT SESSION AT THE CITY OF PHILADELPHIA.
TO DECIDE IF IT BE EXPEDIENT, AT THIS TIME TO DETERMINE UPON ANY PLACE FOR THE PERMANENT SEAT OF THE GOVERNMENT. (VICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE NEGATIVE.)
TO AMEND THE BILL TO DETERMINE THE PERMANENT SEAT OF CONGRESS AND THE U.S. GOVERNMENT; TO INSERT "THE EASTERLY BANK OF THE POTOMAC", AS A SITE FOR THE GOVERNMENT.
TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL; TO INSERT BALTIMORE AS A SITE FOR CONGRESS.  (P. 986)
TO POSTPONE, FOR TWO WEEKS, CONSIDERATION OF THE HOUSE RESOLUTION TO HOLD THE NEXT SESSION OF CONGRESS IN THE TOWN OF BALTIMORE.  (P. 989)

TO AMEND H.R. 178, (1 STAT 138, APP. 8-4-1790), TO MAKE PROVISIONS FOR THE DEBTS OF THE U.S., SO AS TO PROVIDE TO DISCHARGE THE ALTERNATIVES PROPOSED IN THE BILL AND TO FUND THE DOMESTIC DEBT OF THE GOVERNMENT AT AN INTEREST OF 4% PER ANNUM.

TO AMEND THE HOUSE BILL (1 STAT 129, APP. 7-5-90), TO AUTHORIZE THE PURCHASE OF WEST POINT; SO AS TO PROVIDE THAT THE PRESIDENT CAUSE TO BE PURCHASED, THAT TRACT OF LAND IN NEW YORK, CALLED WEST POINT.
TO PASS THE HOUSE BILL (1 STAT 129, APP. 7-5-90), TO AUTHORIZE THE PURCHASE OF WEST POINT.  (P. 994)
TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL SO AS TO MAKE BALTIMORE THE PERMANENT SEAT OF CONGRESS AND GOVERNMENT.
TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL SO AS TO DESIGNATE A SITE ON THE RIVER POTOMAC AS THE SITE FOR THE PERMANANT SEAT OF GOVERNMENT.
TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL TO CHANGE THE DATE AT WHICH THE BUILDINGS FOR THE ACCOMMODATION OF THE GOVERNMENT ARE TO BE READY, TO THE FIRST MONDAY IN DEC. OF 1794.

TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL TO PROVIDE "THAT THE COMMISSIONERS APPOINTED SHALL HAVE POWER TO PURCHASE MUCH LAND ON THE EASTERN SIDE OF THE POTOMAC RIVER, AS THE PRESIDENT SHALL DEEM PROPER, AND SAID COMMISSIONERS SHALL PROVIDE PRIOR TO DECEMBER, 180, SUITABLE BUILDINGS FOR THE ACCOMODATION OF THE GOVERNMENT."

TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL; TO STRIKE THE THIRD, FOURTH AND FIFTH ENACTING CLAUSES AND TO INSERT:  "FOR DEFRAYING THE EXPENSE, THE PRESIDENT SHALL ACCEPT GRANTS OF MONEY AND CAUSE TO BE BORROWED A CERTAIN SUM OF MONEY."

TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL TO PROVIDE THAT THE SEAT OF GOVERNMENT SHALL BE TRANSFERRED ON THE FIRST DAY IN DECEMBER 1800, AND THAT EXPENSES OF SAID MOVE SHALL BE DEFRAYED OUT OF DUTIES ON IMPORTS AND TONNAGE.
TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL SO AS TO ESTABLISH N.Y. CITY AS A TEMPORARY SITE.
TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL, SO AS TO PROVIDE THAT THE TEMPORARY SITE FOR THE GOVERNMENT SHALL RESIDE IN NEW YORK CITY UNTIL 1800.
TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL SO AS TO PROVIDE THAT NEW YORK CITY SHALL REMAIN THE TEMPORARY SEAT UNTIL DEC., 1800.

TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL SO THAT IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK, UNTIL DEC. 1794, (AFTER WHICH DATE) IT READ "THAT CONGRESS SHALL CONTINUE TO HOLD THEIR SESSIONS CONGRESS SHALL HOLD THEIR SESSIONS IN THE CITY OF PHILADELPHIA UNTIL DEC. 800."
TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL, SO AS TO PROVIDE THAT BEGINNING DEC., 1794, BALTIMORE SHALL BE A TEMPORARY SEAT OF GOVERNMENT.
TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL TO PROVIDE THAT THE TEMPORARY SEAT OF GOVERNMENT SHALL CHANGE FROM NEW YORK TO PHILADELPHIA IN DEC., OF 1792.  (VICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE NEGATIVE)

TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL TO PROVIDE "PRIOR TO THE FIRST MONDAY OF NEXT DEC., ALL OFFICES ATTACHED TO THE SEAT OF THE GOVERNMENT, SHALL BE REMOVED TO PHILADELPHIA UNTIL THE FIRST MONDAY IN DEC., 1800; AT WHICH PLACE THE TWO HOUSES DO RESOLVE THATTHE NEXT SESSION OF CONGRESS SHALL BE HELD."  (VICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE NEGATIVE)
TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL, SO AS TO PROVIDE THAT PHILADELPHIA SHALL BE THE TEMPORARY SEAT OF GOVERNMENT FROM DEC. 1790 TO DEC. 1800.
TO AMEND THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL SO AS TO STRIKE THE PROVI- SION TO BORROW A CERTAIN SUM OF MONEY TO BE USED FOR THE PURCHASE OF LAND AND BUILDING FOR THE PERMANENT SEAT OF GOVERNMENT.
TO ORDER THIRD READING OF THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL.
TO AMEND THE 5TH ENACTING CLAUSE OF THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL SO AS TO MAKE MAY 1790, THE DATE FOR THE MOVING OF THE SEAT OF GOVERNMENT TO PHILADELPHIA.  (VICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE NEGATIVE)
TO PASS THE GOVERNMENT SEAT BILL.

TO AGREE TO THE RESOLUTION CONTAINED IN A COMMITTEE REPORT CONCERNING GOVERNMENT LOANS; SAID RESOLUTION PROPOSES A $21 MILLION LOAN TO BE REGULATED UNDER THE PROVISIONS CONCERNING THE DOMESTIC DEBT OF THE U.S.

TO PASS A RESOLUTION CONTAINED IN THE DEBT REPORT; TO PRO- VIDE THAT IF THE ENTIRE AMOUNT INDICATED IN THE DEBT OR CERTIFICATES OF ANY STATE, SHALL NOT BE SUBSCRIBED WITHIN THE TIME LIMIT, SUCH STATE SHALL BE ENTITLED TO RECEIVE FROM THE U.S. A SUM IN TRST UNTIL ALL BALANCES ARE REMOVED.
TO ADOPT THE PREAMBLE OF A COMMITTEE REPORT ON THE MOTION "THAT PROVISION SHALL BE MADE AT THE NEXT SESSION OF CONGRESS, FOR LOANING TO THE U.S., A CERTAIN SUM."
TO REFER THE LOAN REPORT, ALONG WITH A RELATED BILL, TO A SPECIAL COMMITTEE.
TO AGREE TO THE LAST CLAUSE OF THE LOAN REPORT WHICH STATES: "COMMITTEE FURTHER RECOMMENDS, THAT THE RESOLUTIONS FOR THE ASSUMPTION, BE ADDED TO THE FUNDING BILL, AND THE WHOLE MADE ONE SYSTEM."

TO AMEND THE HOUSE BILL (1 STAT 138, APP. 8-4-90), TO MAKE PROVISIONS FOR THE DEBT OF THE U.S.; TO FUND THE BILLS OF CREDIT ISSUED BY THE AUTHORITY OF THE U.S., AT THE RATE OF FORTY CERTIFICATES FOR ONE DOLLAR IN SPECIE.
TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL SO AS TO PROVIDE THAT CERTIFICATES SHALL BE ISSUED TO ALL SUBSCRIBERS TO THE LOAN; AMENDMENT ALSO STIPULATES TERMS OF THE LOAN.

TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO THE FOURTH SECTION OF THE DEBT BILL SO THAT IT READ, "THAT FOR THE WHOLE OR PART OF ANY SUM SUBSCRIBED TO THE SAID LOAN BY ANY PERSONS, WHICH SHALL BE PAID IN THE PRINCIPAL AND INTEREST OF THE SAID DOMESTIC DEBT," SO AS TO ENABLETHE SUBSCRIBERS TO LOAN TO PAY THEIR SUBSCRIPTIONS IN INTEREST, AS WELL AS PRINCIPAL.

TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL SO AS TO PROVIDE THAT THE SECOND CERTIFICATE GIVEN THE SUBSCRIBER, SHOULD ENTITLE HIM TO "A SUM TO BE EXPRESSED THEREIN, EQUAL TO A CERTAIN PROPORTION, WHICH AFTER 1800, SHALL BEAR AN INTEREST OF SIX PER CENT."

TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL, SO THAT IT READS "TO ENTITLE THE SUBSCRIBERS, FOR ANY SUM SUBSCRIBED TO THE SAID LOAN, AND WHICH SHALL BE PAID ON THE INTEREST OF THE DOMESTIC DEBT, TO A CERTIFICATE FOR THE SUM SUBSCRIBED, BEARING AN INTEREST OF FUR PER CENT."

TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL, SO THAT IT READ "TO ENTITLE THE SUBSCRIBER, FOR ANY SUM SUBSCRIBED TO THE SAID LOAN, AND WHICH SHALL BE PAID IN THE INTEREST OF THE DOMES- TIC DEBT; TO A CERTIFICATE FOR SUCH SUM SUBSCRIBED, BEARING AN INTEREST OF IX PER CENT."
TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL SO AS TO MAKE THE INTEREST ON CERTIFICATES ISSUED BE 4%.
TO AMEND THE DEBT BILL, SO AS TO STRIKE OUT SIX SECTIONS WHICH PERTAIN TO THE RULES AND REGULATIONS OF RAISING A LOAN OF 21 MILLION, FIVE HUNDRED THOUSAND DOLLARS.
TO PASS THE DEBT BILL.

TO AGREE TO THE SECOND HOUSE AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL; TO ENTITLE THE SUBSCRIBER TO A SECOND CERTIFICATE FOR $33 1/3 OF THE SUM SUBSCRIBED, INSTEAD OF $26.88, ON EVERY HUNDRED; HIS SECOND OR DEFERRED CERTIFICATE TO BEAR AN INTEREST OF 6% AFTER 1800.  (ICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE AFFIRMATIVE)

TO DISAGREE TO THE THIRD HOUSE AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL; TO ENTITLE THE SUBSCRIBER TO AN INTEREST OF SIX PER CENT ON HIS DEFERRED CERTIFICATE AFTER 1797, RATHER THAN 1800. (VICE PRESIDENT VOTING IN THE NEGATIVE.)
TO AGREE TO THE FIFTH HOUSE AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL, TO CHANGE THE INTEREST FROM THREE TO FOUR PER CENT ON SUCH PART OF SUBSCRIPTIONS AS MAY BE PAID IN THE ARREARS OF INTEREST.

TO AGREE TO THE 8TH AMENDMENT OF THE HOUSE TO THE DEBT BILL, WHICH WOULD ENTITLE THE SUBSCRIBER TO A SECOND CERTIFICATE FOR THIRTY-THREE DOLLARS AND ONE THIRD OF A DOLLAR, PER CENT, INSTEAD OF TWENTY-SIX DOLLARS AND EIGHT-EIGHT CENTS, ON EVERY HUNDRED; TE SAID SECOND CERTIFICATE TO BE ON INTEREST AT SIX PER CENT AFTER THE YEAR 1800.
TO AGREE TO THE NINTH HOUSE AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL, WHICH PROVIDES THAT THE SUBSCRIBER SHALL BE ENTITLED TO 6% INTEREST ON THE DEFERRED PART OF THE SUM SUBSCRIBED, AFTER THE YEAR 1797.

TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE BY WHICH THE SENATE AGREED TO THE 3RD AMENDMENT OF THE HOUSE TO THE DEBT BILL, WHICH AMENDMENT PROVIDES THAT THE SUBSCRIBER SHALL BE ENTITLED TO AN INTEREST OF SIX PER CENT ON HIS DEFERRED CERTIFICATE, AFTER THE YEAR 1797, INSTEAD F 1800.

TO AGREE TO THE THIRD HOUSE AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL, WHICH PROVIDES THAT THE SUBSCRIBER SHALL BE ENTITLED TO AN INTEREST OF SIX PER CENT ON HIS DEFERRED CERTIFICATE AFTER THE YEAR 1797, INSTEAD OF 1800.

TO AGREE TO THE HOUSE AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL, WHICH PROVIDES THAT THE U.S. MAY REDEEM BY ANNUAL PAYMENTS, ON ACCOUNT OF PRINCIPAL AND INTEREST, THE ASSUMED PART OF THE DEBT, AT THE RATE OF EIGHT PER CENT INSTEAD OF SEVEN PER CENT PER ANNUM.  (VICE PRSIDENT VOTING IN THE AFFIRMATIVE)
TO AGREE TO THE HOUSE AMENDMENT TO THE DEBT BILL WHICH WOULD CHANGE TO 4%, THE INTEREST ON 1/3 OF THE SUBSCRIBED SUM.
TO REFER TO A SELECT COMMITTEE THE TREATY BETWEEN THE U.S. AND THE CREEK INDIANS.

TO AGREE TO THE RESOLUTION THAT ON THE FINAL QUESTION, WHEN THE ADVICE AND CONSENT OF THE SENATE IS REQUESTED, ANY MEM- BER SHALL HAVE A RIGHT TO ENTER HIS PROTEST OR DISSENT ON THE JOURNAL, WITH REASON IN SUPPORT OF SUCH DISSENT.
TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF THE TREATY WITH THE CREEK INDIANS.

TO PASS THE SUBSTITUTE RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT IT BE INEXPEDIENT TO ALTER THE SYSTEM OF FUNDING THE PUBLIC DEBT ESTABLISHED DURING THE LAST SESSION OF CONGRESS AND THAT THE PETITION OF THOS. MC KEAN AND OTHERS BE REJECTED.  (P. 1739)

TO AMEND THE SENATE BILL (1 STAT 191, 2-25-1791), INCORPORA- TING THE SUBSCRIBERS OF THE BANK OF THE U.S., BY EXTENDING THE TERM OF INCORPORATION TO MARCH 4, 1815, INSTEAD OF LIMITING TERM OF INCORPORATION TO 7 YEARS.  (P. 1745)
TO AMEND BANK OF THE U.S. BILL, BY FURTHER LIMITING OF TERM OF INCORPORATION FROM 1811 TO 1801.  (P. 1748)
TO AMEND BANK OF THE U.S. BILL, BY ELIMINATING THE PROVISION THAT PREVENTS ESTABLISHMENT OF ANY OTHER BANK BY FUTURE LAW OF THE U.S. DURING THE CONTINUATION OF THE BANK OF THE U.S. (P. 1748)

TO AMEND THE HOUSE BILL (1 STAT 199, 3-3-1791), REPEALING AFTER THE LAST DAY OF JUNE NEXT THE DUTIES HERETOFORE LAID UPON DISTILLED SPIRITS IMPORTED FROM ABROAD, AND LAYING OTHERS IN THEIR STEAD, AND ALSO UPON SPIRITS DISTILLED WITHIN THE U.S. BY ELIMINAING THE PROVISION GRANTING TO THE PRESIDENT THE POWER TO MAKE APPOINTMENTS OF REVENUE OFFICERS DURING RECESS OF THE SENATE; SUCH APPOINTMENTS TO EXPIRE AT END OF NEXT SESSION

TO PASS THE HOUSE BILL (1 STAT 199, 3-3-1791), REPEALING AFTER THE LAST DAY OF JUNE NEXT, THE DUTIES HERETOFORE LAID UPON DISTILLED SPIRITS IMPORTED FROM ABROAD AND LAYING OTHERS IN THEIR STEAD, AND ALSO UPON SPIRITS DISTILLED IN THE UNITED STATES.  (P. 3,89)
TO CONSIDER THE SENATE BILL (1 STAT 214, 3-3-1791), AMENDING THE ACT ESTABLISHING THE TEMPORARY AND PERMANENT SEAT OF THE U.S. GOVERNMENT.  (P. 1759)

TO ADOPT THE FIRST SECTION OF THE HOUSE BILL (1 STAT 222, 3-3-1791), INCREASING THE MILITARY ESTABLISHMENT OF THE U.S., WHICH SECTION PROVIDES THAT THERE SHALL BE RAISED AN ADDITIONAL REGIMENT OF INFANTRY, WHICH, EXCLUSIVE OF THE COMMISSIONED OFFICERS SHLL CONSIST OF 912 NON-COMMISSIONED OFFICERS, PRIVATES AND MUSICIANS.
TO POSTPONE FOR ONE WEEK CONSIDERATION OF THE SENATE BILL (1 STAT 214, 3-3-1791), AMENDING THE ACT ESTABLISHING THE TEMPORARY AND PERMANENT SEAT OF THE U.S. GOVERNMENT. (P. 1759)

TO AGREE TO AMENDMENT TO THE 1ST SECTION OF THE BILL (1 STAT 222, 3-3-1791), AN ACT FOR RAISING AND ADDING ANOTH- ER REGIMENT TO THE MILITARY ESTABLISHMENT OF THE U.S. AND FOR MAKING FURTHER PROVISION FOR THE PROTECTIONS OF THE FRONTIERS, WHICH AMENDMENTREDUCES THE NUMBER OF THE REGIMENT TO 608, INSTEAD OF 912 NON-COMMISSIONED OFFICERS, PRIVATES AND MUSICIANS

TO INSIST ON THE AMENDMENT TO THE AMENDMENT OF THE HOUSE TO THE HOUSE BILL (1 STAT 199, 3-3-1791), REPEALING AFTER JUNE 30 NEXT, THE DUTIES HERETOFORE LAID UPON DISTILLED SPIRITS AND LAYING OTHERS IN THEIR PLACE, WHICH AMENDMENT REDUCES FROM 7 TO 5 PER CNT OF THE AMOUNT OF THE DUTIES PRODUCED BY THIS ACT AS THE LIMIT OF THE TOTAL TO BE PAID TO DEPUTIES, INSPECTORS AND OFFICERS FOR THEIR SERVICES IN EXECUTING THIS ACT
TO READ FOR THE 3RD TIME THE HOUSE BILL (1 STAT 196, 3-2-91) TO INCORPORATE THE SUBSCRIBERS TO THE BANK OF THE U.S.

TO PASS THE RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT IT BE A STANDING RULE THAT THE DOORS OF THE SENATE REMAIN OPEN, EXCEPT WHEN THE SENATE SHALL DESIRE SECRECY, AND THAT THIS RULE SHALL BE IN FORCE FROM THE FIRST DAY OF THE NEXT SESSION OF CONGRESS. (P. 1768)
TO POSTPONE FURTHER CONSIDERATION OF THE SENATE BILL (1 STAT 214, 3-3-1791), TO AMEND AN ACT ESTABLISHING THE TEMPORARY AND PERMANENT SEAT OF THE GOVERNMENT OF THE U.S.

TO AGREE TO THE FIRST CLAUSE OF THE SENATE BILL (1 STAT 214, 3-3-1791), AMENDING AN ACT ESTABLISHING THE TEMPORARY AND PERMANENT SEAT OF THE U.S. GOVERNMENT, WHICH CLAUSE AUTHORIZES THE PRESIDENT TO MAKE ANY PART OF THE TERRITORY BELOW THE LIMITS ON THE OTOMAC RIVER AND ABOVE HUNTING CREEK, A PART OF THE DISTRICT, SO AS TO INCLUDE A CONVENIENT PART OF THE EASTERN BRANCH AND THE LANDS LYING ON THE LOWER SIDE THEREOF AND ALSO THE TOWN OF ALEXANDRIA; AND THE TERRITORY SO TO BE INCLUDED SHALL FORM A PART OF ...

TO AMEND THE HOUSE BILL (1 STAT 196, 3/2/1791), SUPPLEMENT- ARY TO AN ACT TO INCORPORATE THE SUBSCRIBERS OF THE BANK OF THE U.S., WHICH AMENDMENT EMPOWERS CONGRESS TO ABOLISH THE CORPORATION KNOWN AS THE BANK OF THE U.S. ANY TIME AFTER MARCH 4, 1802.  (P 1769)

TO PASS THE AMENDED BILL, (1 STAT 216, APP. 3-3-1791), IN ADDITION TO AN ACT TO ESTABLISH THE SALARIES OF THE EXECUT- IVE OFFICERS OF THE GOVERNMENT, WITH THEIR ASSISTANTS AND CLERKS, WHICH BILL INCREASES THE SALARY OF THE CHIEF CLERK OF THE AUDITOR $200A YEAR, AND THAT OF THE SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY $400, A YEAR AND ALLOWS TO THE CLERKS EMPLOYED IN THE GOVERNMENT THEIR REASONABLE AND NECESSARY EXPENSES INCURRED BY THE REMOVAL OF CONGRESS FROM N.Y

TO READ THE SECOND TIME THE HOUSE BILL, CARRYING INTO EFFECT THE CONVENTION BETWEEN THE U.S. AND FRANCE, ENTERED INTO FOR THE PURPOSE OF DEFINING AND ESTABLISHING THE FUNCTIONS AND PRIVILEGES OF THEIR RESPECTIVE, CONSULS, MOTION DEFEATED, BECAUSE THE RUL REQUIRES UNANIMOUS, CONSENT IN ORDER THAT A BILL MAY BE READ TWICE ON THE SAME DAY.
